review.title: Service Choreography, SBVR, and Time
review.abstract: We propose the use of structured natural language (English) in specifying service choreographies, focusing on the what rather than the how of the required coordination of participant services in realising a business application scenario. The declarative approach we propose uses the OMG standard Semantics of Business Vocabulary and Rules (SBVR) as a modelling language. The service choreography approach has been proposed for describing the global orderings of the invocations on interfaces of participant services. We therefore extend SBVR with a notion of time which can capture the coordination of the participant services, in terms of the observable message exchanges between them. The extension is done using existing modelling constructs in SBVR, and hence respects the standard specification. The idea is that users - domain specialists rather than implementation specialists - can verify the requested service composition by directly reading the structured English used by SBVR. At the same time, the SBVR model can be represented in formal logic so it can be parsed and executed by a machine.

sections.heading: 2 The Business Rules approach and SBVR
sections.text: Multiple specification or modeling languages for specifying interactions between services in a business application scenario are available to practitioners with different application levels, such as Business Process Model Notation (BPMN) [25], Web Services Choreography Description Language (WS-CDL) [34], Web Services Business Process Execution Language (WS-BPEL) [26]. These languages require literacy and writing training and are therefore not naturally suitable for use by the end user. OMG standard semantics of Business Vocabulary and Rules (SBVR) are gaining ground as a basis for system specifications. With the introduction, SBVR is intended to provide a way to capture specifications in natural language and display them in formal logic so that they can be processed by machine. Users are able to verify the specification directly by reading the natural language used by SBVR, which can then be executed by a machine.

sections.heading: 3 Service Choreography Specification using SBVR
sections.text: In this section we describe how to create an SBVR model for the service choreography in the online photo shop, which was originally investigated in [21]. We identify the need to express the ordering relationship between observable events and propose a way to express such orders in an SBVR model.

sections.heading: 3.1 Online Photo Shop: a case study
sections.text: We are looking at the case study of an online photo business in [21] that provides services for ordering and printing photos (and other products) to customers. The business scenario involves a multi-party conversation between several services; customer, photo shop, ordering, printing and delivery. All services are provided by the online photo business unit, so they all belong to one organization. The conversation respects the policy that underlines the business activities involved, as described in [21]. However, we note that there are certain issues with the specification of the online photo business, as in [21], such as ambiguities in the definition of an activity (e.g. "open order" and "register"), while some prescribed orders on activities are questionable (e.g. the customer can "pay before or after the photo store."
